verses.textEn: In many places and in many ways, in past times, God spoke to the fathers through the Prophets;
verses.textLa: Multifariam, multisque modis olim Deus loquens patribus in Prophetis:
verses.notes: The word ‘multifariam’ refers more to places (or parts) than to times; time is referred to in ‘olim,’ which is ‘past times.’

verses.textEn: lastly, in these days, he has spoken to us through the Son, whom he appointed as the heir of all things, and through whom he made the world.
verses.textLa: novissime, diebus istis locutus est nobis in Filio, quem constituit heredem universorum, per quem fecit et sæcula:

verses.textEn: And since the Son is the brightness of his glory, and the figure of his substance, and is carrying all things by the Word of his virtue, thereby accomplishing a purging of sins, he sits at the right hand of Majesty on high.
verses.textLa: qui cum sit splendor gloriæ, et figura substantiæ eius, portansque omnia verbo virtutis suæ, purgationem peccatorum faciens, sedet ad dexteram Maiestatis in excelsis:
verses.notes: The Son is the brightness of the Father’s glory and the visible figure of the Father’s invisible substance, and the Word of the Son is of the Power of the Father.

verses.textEn: And having been made so much better than the Angels, he has inherited a name so much greater than theirs.
verses.textLa: tanto melior Angelis effectus, quanto differentius præ illis nomen hereditavit.

verses.textEn: For to which of the Angels has he ever said: “You are my Son; today have I begotten you?” Or again: “I will be a Father to him, and he shall be a Son to me?”
verses.textLa: Cui enim dixit aliquando Angelorum: Filius meus es tu, ego hodie genui te? Et rursum: Ego ero illi in Patrem, et ipse erit mihi in Filium?

verses.textEn: And again, when he brings the only-begotten Son into the world, he says: “And let all the Angels of God adore him.”
verses.textLa: Et cum iterum introducit primogenitum in orbem terræ, dicit: Et adorent eum omnes Angeli Dei.

verses.textEn: And about the Angels, certainly, he says: “He makes his Angels spirits, and his ministers a flame of fire.”
verses.textLa: Et ad Angelos quidem dicit: Qui facit Angelos suos spiritus, et ministros suos flammam ignis.

verses.textEn: But about the Son: “Your throne, O God, is forever and ever. The scepter of your kingdom is a scepter of equity.
verses.textLa: Ad Filium autem: Thronus tuus Deus in sæculum sæculi: virga æquitatis, virga regni tui.

verses.textEn: You have loved justice, and you have hated iniquity. Because of this, God, your God, has anointed you with the oil of exultation, above your companions.”
verses.textLa: Dilexisti iustitiam, et odisti iniquitatem: propterea unxit te Deus, Deus tuus oleo exultationis præ participibus tuis.

verses.textEn: And: “In the beginning, O Lord, you founded the earth. And the heavens are the work of your hands.
verses.textLa: Et: Tu in principio Domine terram fundasti: et opera manuum tuarum sunt cæli.

verses.textEn: These shall pass away, but you will remain. And all will grow old like a garment.
verses.textLa: Ipsi peribunt, tu autem permanebis, et omnes ut vestimentum veterascent:

verses.textEn: And you will change them like a cloak, and they shall be changed. Yet you are ever the same, and your years will not diminish.”
verses.textLa: et velut amictum mutabis eos, et mutabuntur: tu autem idem ipse es, et anni tui non deficient.

verses.textEn: But to which of the Angels has he ever said: “Sit at my right hand, until I make your enemies your footstool?”
verses.textLa: Ad quem autem Angelorum dixit aliquando: Sede a dextris meis, quoadusque ponam inimicos tuos scabellum pedum tuorum?

verses.textEn: Are they not all spirits of ministration, sent to minister for the sake of those who shall receive the inheritance of salvation?
verses.textLa: Nonne omnes sunt administratorii spiritus, in ministerium missi propter eos, qui hereditatem capient salutis?

verses.textEn: For this reason, it is necessary for us to observe more thoroughly the things that we have heard, lest we let them slip away.
verses.textLa: Propterea abundantius oportet observare nos ea, quæ audivimus ne forte pereffluamus.

verses.textEn: For if a word that was spoken through the Angels has been made firm, and every transgression and disobedience has received the recompense of a just retribution,
verses.textLa: Si enim qui per Angelos dictus est sermo, factus est firmus, et omnis prævaricatio, et inobedientia accepit iustam mercedis retributionem:

verses.textEn: in what way might we escape, if we neglect such a great salvation? For though initially it had begun to be described by the Lord, it was confirmed among us by those who heard him,
verses.textLa: quomodo nos effugiemus si tantam neglexerimus salutem? Quæ cum initium accepisset enarrari per Dominum ab eis, qui audierunt, in nos confirmata est,

verses.textEn: with God testifying to it by signs and wonders, and by various miracles, and by the pouring out of the Holy Spirit, in accord with his own will.
verses.textLa: contestante Deo signis et portentis, et variis virtutibus, et Spiritus Sancti distributionibus secundum suam voluntatem.

verses.textEn: For God did not subject the future world, about which we are speaking, to the Angels.
verses.textLa: Non enim Angelis subiecit Deus orbem terræ futurum, de quo loquimur.

verses.textEn: But someone, in a certain place, has testified, saying: “What is man, that you are mindful of him, or the Son of man, that you visit him?
verses.textLa: Testatus est autem in quodam loco quis, dicens: Quid est homo quod memor es eius, aut Filius hominis quoniam visitas eum?

verses.textEn: You have reduced him to a little less than the Angels. You have crowned him with glory and honor, and you have set him over the works of your hands.
verses.textLa: Minuisti eum paulo minus ab Angelis: gloria et honore coronasti eum: et constituisti eum super opera manuum tuarum.

verses.textEn: You have subjected all things under his feet.” For in as much as he has subjected all things to him, he has left nothing not subject to him. But in the present time, we do not yet perceive that all things have been made subject to him.
verses.textLa: Omnia subiecisti sub pedibus eius: In eo enim quod omnia ei subiecit, nihil dimisit non subiectum ei. Nunc autem necdum videmus omnia subiecta ei.

verses.textEn: Yet we understand that Jesus, who was reduced to a little less than the Angels, was crowned with glory and honor because of his Passion and death, in order that, by the grace of God, he might taste death for all.
verses.textLa: Eum autem, qui modico quam Angeli minoratus est, videmus Iesum propter passionem mortis, gloria et honore coronatum: ut gratia Dei, pro omnibus gustaret mortem.

verses.textEn: For it was fitting for him, because of whom and through whom all things exist, who had led many children into glory, to complete the authorship of their salvation through his Passion.
verses.textLa: Decebat enim eum, propter quem omnia, et per quem omnia, qui multos filios in gloriam adduxerat, auctorem salutis eorum per passionem consummare.

verses.textEn: For he who sanctifies, and those who are sanctified, are all from One. For this reason, he is not ashamed to call them brothers, saying:
verses.textLa: Qui enim sanctificat, et qui sanctificantur, ex uno omnes. Propter quam causam non confunditur fratres eos vocare, dicens:

verses.textEn: “I will announce your name to my brothers. In the midst of the Church, I will praise you.”
verses.textLa: Nunciabo nomen tuum fratribus meis: in medio Ecclesiæ laudabo te.

verses.textEn: And again: “I will be faithful in him.” And again: “Behold, I and my children, whom God has given to me.”
verses.textLa: Et iterum: Ego ero fidens in eum. Et iterum: Ecce ego, et pueri mei, quos dedit mihi Deus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, because children have a common flesh and blood, he himself also, in like manner, has shared in the same, so that through death, he might destroy him who held the dominion of death, that is, the devil,
verses.textLa: Quia ergo pueri communicaverunt carni, et sanguini, et ipse similiter participavit eisdem: ut per mortem destrueret eum, qui habebat mortis imperium, id est, diabolum:

verses.textEn: and so that he might free those who, through the fear of death, had been condemned to servitude throughout their entire life.
verses.textLa: et liberaret eos, qui timore mortis per totam vitam obnoxii erant servituti.

verses.textEn: For at no time did he take hold of the Angels, but instead he took hold of the offspring of Abraham.
verses.textLa: Nusquam enim Angelos apprehendit, sed semen Abrahæ apprehendit.
verses.notes: This refers to the Incarnation, by which God became a man, not an angel.

verses.textEn: Therefore, it is fitting for him to be made similar to his brothers in all things, so that he might become a merciful and faithful High Priest before God, in order that he might bring forgiveness to the offenses of the people.
verses.textLa: Unde debuit per omnia fratribus similari, ut misericors fieret, et fidelis Pontifex ad Deum, ut repropitiaret delicta populi.

verses.textEn: For in as much as he himself has suffered and has been tempted, he also is able to assist those who are tempted.
verses.textLa: In eo enim, in quo passus est ipse et tentatus, potens est et eis, qui tentantur, auxiliari.

verses.textEn: Therefore, holy brothers, sharers in the heavenly calling, consider the Apostle and High Priest of our confession: Jesus.
verses.textLa: Unde fratres sancti, vocationis cælestis participes, considerate Apostolum, et Pontificem confessionis nostræ Iesum:

verses.textEn: He is faithful to the One who made him, just as Moses also was, with his entire house.
verses.textLa: qui fidelis est ei, qui fecit illum sicut et Moyses in omni domo eius.

verses.textEn: For this Jesus was considered worthy of greater glory than Moses, so much so that the house which he has built holds a greater honor than the former one.
verses.textLa: Amplioris enim gloriæ iste præ Moyse dignus est habitus, quanto ampliorem honorem habet domus, qui fabricavit illam.

verses.textEn: For every house is built by someone, but God is the One who has created all things.
verses.textLa: Omnis namque domus fabricatur ab aliquo: qui autem omnia creavit, Deus est.

verses.textEn: And certainly Moses was faithful, with his entire house, like any servant, as a testimony to those things that would soon be said.
verses.textLa: Et Moyses quidem fidelis erat in tota domo eius tamquam famulus, in testimonium eorum, quæ dicenda erant:

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Christ is like a Son in his own house. We are that house, if we firmly retain the faithfulness and the glory of hope, even unto the end.
verses.textLa: Christus vero tamquam filius in domo sua: quæ domus sumus nos, si fiduciam, et gloriam spei usque ad finem, firmam retineamus.

verses.textEn: Because of this, it is just as the Holy Spirit says: “If today you hear his voice,
verses.textLa: Quapropter sicut dicit Spiritus Sanctus: Hodie si vocem eius audieritis,

verses.textEn: harden not your hearts, as in the provocation, the very day of temptation, in the desert,
verses.textLa: nolite obdurare corda vestra, sicut in exacerbatione secundum diem tentationis in deserto,

verses.textEn: where your fathers tested me, even though they had seen and examined my works for forty years.
verses.textLa: ubi tentaverunt me patres vestri: probaverunt, et viderunt opera mea quadraginta annis:

verses.textEn: For this reason, I was enraged against this generation, and I said: They always wander astray in heart. For they have not known my ways.
verses.textLa: Propter quod infensus fui generationi huic, et dixi: Semper errant corde. Ipsi autem non cognoverunt vias meas,

verses.textEn: So it is as I swore in my wrath: They shall not enter into my rest!”
verses.textLa: sicut iuravi in ira mea: Si introibunt in requiem meam.

verses.textEn: Be cautious, brothers, lest perhaps there may be, in any of you, an evil heart of unbelief, turning aside from the living God.
verses.textLa: Videte fratres, ne forte sit in aliquo vestrum cor malum incredulitatis, discedendi a Deo vivo:

verses.textEn: Instead, exhort one another every day, while it is still called ‘today,’ so that none of you may become hardened through the falseness of sin.
verses.textLa: sed adhortamini vosmetipsos per singulos dies, donec Hodie cognominatur, ut non obduretur quis ex vobis fallacia peccati.

verses.textEn: For we have been made participants in Christ. This is only so, if we firmly retain the beginning of his substance, even unto the end.
verses.textLa: Participes enim Christi effecti sumus: si tamen initium substantiæ eius usque ad finem firmum retineamus.

verses.textEn: For it has been said: “If today you hear his voice, harden not your hearts, in the same manner as in the former provocation.”
verses.textLa: Dum dicitur: Hodie si vocem eius audieritis, nolite obdurare corda vestra, quemadmodum in illa exacerbatione.

verses.textEn: For some of those listening did provoke him. But not all of these had set forth from Egypt through Moses.
verses.textLa: Quidam enim audientes exacerbaverunt: sed non universi qui profecti sunt ex Ægypto per Moysen.

verses.textEn: So against whom was he angry for forty years? Was it not those who had sinned, whose dead bodies lay prostrate in the desert?
verses.textLa: Quibus autem infensus est quadraginta annis? Nonne illis, qui peccaverunt, quorum cadavera prostrata sunt in deserto?

verses.textEn: But to whom did he swear that they would not enter into his rest, except to those who were incredulous?
verses.textLa: Quibus autem iuravit non introire in requiem ipsius, nisi illis, qui increduli fuerunt?

verses.textEn: And so, we perceive that they were not able to enter because of unbelief.
verses.textLa: Et videmus, quia non potuerunt introire propter incredulitatem.

verses.textEn: Therefore, we should be afraid, lest the promise of entering into his rest may be relinquished, and some of you may be judged to be lacking.
verses.textLa: Timeamus ergo ne forte relicta pollicitatione introeundi in requiem eius, existimetur aliquis ex vobis deesse.

verses.textEn: For this was announced to us in a similar manner as to them. But the mere hearing of the word did not benefit them, since it was not joined together with a faith in those things that they heard.
verses.textLa: Etenim et nobis nunciatum est, quemadmodum et illis. Sed non profuit illis sermo auditus, non admistus fidei ex iis, quæ audierunt.

verses.textEn: For we who have believed shall enter into rest, in the same manner as he said: “So it is as I have sworn in my wrath: They shall not enter into my rest!” And certainly, this is when the works from the foundation of the world have been finished.
verses.textLa: Ingrediemur enim in requiem, qui credidimus: quemadmodum dixit: Sicut iuravi in ira mea: Si introibunt in requiem meam: et quidem operibus ab institutione mundi perfectis.

verses.textEn: For, in a certain place, he spoke about the seventh day in this manner: “And God rested on the seventh day from all his works.”
verses.textLa: Dixit enim in quodam loco de die septima sic: Et requievit Deus die septima ab omnibus operibus suis.

verses.textEn: And in this place again: “They shall not enter into my rest!”
verses.textLa: Et in isto rursum: Si introibunt in requiem meam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, this is because certain ones remain who are to enter into it, and those to whom it was announced first did not enter into it, because of unbelief.
verses.textLa: Quoniam ergo superest introire quosdam in illam, et ii, quibus prioribus annunciatum est, non introierunt propter incredulitatem:

verses.textEn: Again, he defines a certain day, after so much time, saying in David, “Today,” just as it was stated above, “If today you hear his voice, harden not your hearts.”
verses.textLa: Iterum terminat diem quendam, Hodie, in David dicendo, post tantum temporis, sicut supra dictum est: Hodie si vocem eius audieritis, nolite obdurare corda vestra.

verses.textEn: For if Jesus had offered them rest, he would never have spoken, afterward, about another day.
verses.textLa: Nam si eis Iesus requiem præstitisset, numquam de alia loqueretur, posthac, die.

verses.textEn: And so, there remains a Sabbath of rest for the people of God.
verses.textLa: Itaque relinquitur Sabbatismus populo Dei.

verses.textEn: For whoever has entered into his rest, the same has also rested from his works, just as God did from his.
verses.textLa: Qui enim ingressus est in requiem eius: etiam ipse requievit ab operibus suis, sicut a suis Deus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, let us hasten to enter into that rest, so that no one may fall into the same example of unbelief.
verses.textLa: Festinemus ergo ingredi in illam requiem: ut ne in idipsum quis incidat incredulitatis exemplum.

verses.textEn: For the Word of God is living and effective: more piercing than any two-edged sword, reaching to the division even between the soul and the spirit, even between the joints and the marrow, and so it discerns the thoughts and intentions of the heart.
verses.textLa: Vivus est enim Sermo Dei, et efficax, et penetrabilior omni gladio ancipiti: et pertingens usque ad divisionem animæ ac spiritus, compagum quoque ac medullarum, et discretor cogitationum et intentionum cordis.
verses.notes: In the ancient view of the human person, when body and soul are united, there exists spirit, that is, the breath of life, and those qualities that pertain to life and to the cooperation of body and soul, such as heart and mind and emotion, etc.

verses.textEn: And there is no created thing that is invisible to his sight. For all things are naked and open to the eyes of him, about whom we are speaking.
verses.textLa: Et non est ulla creatura invisibilis in conspectu eius: omnia autem nuda et aperta sunt oculis eius, ad quem nobis sermo.

verses.textEn: Therefore, since we have a great High Priest, who has pierced the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, we should hold to our confession.
verses.textLa: Habentes ergo Pontificem magnum, qui penetravit cælos, Iesum Filium Dei: teneamus confessionem.

verses.textEn: For we do not have a high priest who is unable to have compassion on our infirmities, but rather one who was tempted in all things, just as we are, yet without sin.
verses.textLa: Non enim habemus pontificem, qui non possit compati infirmitatibus nostris: tentatum autem per omnia pro similitudine absque peccato.

verses.textEn: Therefore, let us go forth with confidence toward the throne of grace, so that we may obtain mercy, and find grace, in a helpful time.
verses.textLa: Adeamus ergo cum fiducia ad thronum gratiæ: ut misericordiam consequamur, et gratiam inveniamus in auxilio opportuno.

verses.textEn: For every high priest, having been taken from among men, is appointed on behalf of men toward the things which pertain to God, so that he may offer gifts and sacrifices on behalf of sins;
verses.textLa: Omnis namque pontifex ex hominibus assumptus, pro hominibus constituitur in iis, quæ sunt ad Deum, ut offerat dona, et sacrificia pro peccatis:

verses.textEn: he is able to commiserate with those who are ignorant and who wander astray, because he himself is also encompassed by infirmity.
verses.textLa: qui condolere possit iis, qui ignorant, et errant: quoniam et ipse circumdatus est infirmitate:

verses.textEn: And because of this, he also must make such offerings for sins even for himself, in the same manner as for the people.
verses.textLa: et propterea debet, quemadmodum pro populo, ita etiam et pro semetipso offerre pro peccatis.

verses.textEn: Neither does anyone take up this honor himself, but rather he who is called by God, just as Aaron was.
verses.textLa: Nec quisquam sumit sibi honorem, sed qui vocatur a Deo, tamquam Aaron.

verses.textEn: Thus, even Christ did not glorify himself, so as to become High Priest, but instead, it was God who said to him: “You are my Son. Today I have begotten you.”
verses.textLa: Sic et Christus non semetipsum clarificavit ut Pontifex fieret: sed qui locutus est ad eum: Filius meus es tu, ego hodie genui te.

verses.textEn: And similarly, he says in another place: “You are a priest forever, according to the order of Melchizedek.”
verses.textLa: Quemadmodum et in alio loco dicit: Tu es sacerdos in æternum, secundum ordinem Melchisedech.

verses.textEn: It is Christ who, in the days of his flesh, with a strong cry and tears, offered prayers and supplications to the One who was able to save him from death, and who was heard because of his reverence.
verses.textLa: Qui in diebus carnis suæ preces, supplicationesque ad eum, qui possit illum salvum facere a morte cum clamore valido, et lacrymis offerens, exauditus est pro sua reverentia:

verses.textEn: And although, certainly, he is the Son of God, he learned obedience by the things that he suffered.
verses.textLa: Et quidem cum esset Filius Dei, didicit ex iis, quæ passus est, obedientiam:

verses.textEn: And having reached his consummation, he was made, for all who are obedient to him, the cause of eternal salvation,
verses.textLa: et consummatus, factus est omnibus obtemperantibus sibi, causa salutis æternæ,

verses.textEn: having been called by God to be the High Priest, according to the order of Melchizedek.
verses.textLa: appellatus a Deo Pontifex iuxta ordinem Melchisedech.

verses.textEn: Our message about him is great, and difficult to explain when speaking, because you have been made feeble when listening.
verses.textLa: De quo nobis grandis sermo, et ininterpretabilis ad dicendum: quoniam imbecilles facti estis ad audiendum.

verses.textEn: For even though it is the time when you ought to be teachers, you are still lacking, so that you must be taught the things that are the basic elements of the Word of God, and so you have been made like those who are in need of milk, and not of solid food.
verses.textLa: Etenim cum deberetis magistri esse propter tempus: rursum indigetis ut vos doceamini quæ sint elementa exordii sermonum Dei: et facti estis quibus lacte opus sit, non solido cibo.

verses.textEn: For anyone who is still feeding on milk is still unskillful in the Word of Justice; for he is like an infant.
verses.textLa: Omnis enim, qui lactis est particeps, expers est sermonis iustitiæ, parvulus enim est.

verses.textEn: But solid food is for those who are mature, for those who, by practice, have sharpened their mind, so as to discern good from evil.
verses.textLa: Perfectorum autem est solidus cibus: eorum, qui pro consuetudine exercitatos habent sensus ad discretionem boni ac mali.

verses.textEn: Therefore, interrupting an explanation of the basics of Christ, let us consider what is more advanced, not presenting again the fundamentals of repentance from dead works, and of faith toward God,
verses.textLa: Quapropter intermittentes inchoationis Christi sermonem, ad perfectiora feramur, non rursum iacientes fundamentum pœnitentiæ ab operibus mortuis, et fidei ad Deum,

verses.textEn: of the doctrine of baptism, and also of the imposition of hands, and of the resurrection of the dead, and of eternal judgment.
verses.textLa: baptismatum doctrinæ, impositionis quoque manuum, ac resurrectionis mortuorum, et iudicii æterni.

verses.textEn: And we shall do this, if indeed God permits it.
verses.textLa: Et hoc faciemus, si quidem permiserit Deus.

verses.textEn: For it is impossible for those who were once illuminated, and have even tasted of the heavenly gift, and have become sharers in the Holy Spirit,
verses.textLa: Impossibile est enim eos, qui semel sunt illuminati, gustaverunt etiam donum cæleste, et participes facti sunt Spiritus Sancti,

verses.textEn: who, despite having tasted the good Word of God and the virtues of the future age, have yet fallen away,
verses.textLa: gustaverunt nihilominus bonum Dei verbum, virtutesque sæculi venturi, et prolapsi sunt;

verses.textEn: to be renewed again to penance, since they are crucifying again in themselves the Son of God and are still maintaining pretenses.
verses.textLa: rursus renovari ad pœnitentiam, rursum crucifigentes sibimetipsis Filium Dei, et ostentui habentes.

verses.textEn: For the earth accepts a blessing from God, by drinking in the rain that often falls upon it, and by producing plants that are useful to those by whom it is cultivated.
verses.textLa: Terra enim sæpe venientem super se bibens imbrem, et generans herbam opportunam illis, a quibus colitur: accipit benedictionem a Deo.

verses.textEn: But whatever brings forth thorns and briers is rejected, and is closest to what is accursed; their consummation is in combustion.
verses.textLa: Proferens autem spinas, ac tribulos, reproba est, et maledicto proxima: cuius consummatio in combustionem.

verses.textEn: But from you, most beloved, we are confident that there will be things better and closer to salvation; even though we speak in this way.
verses.textLa: Confidimus autem de vobis dilectissimi meliora, et viciniora saluti: tametsi ita loquimur.

verses.textEn: For God is not unjust, such that he would forget your work and the love that you have shown in his name. For you have ministered, and you continue to minister, to the saints.
verses.textLa: Non enim iniustus Deus, ut obliviscatur operis vestri, et dilectionis, quam ostendistis in nomine ipsius, qui ministrastis sanctis, et ministratis.

verses.textEn: Yet we desire that each one of you display the same solicitude toward the fulfillment of hope, even unto the end,
verses.textLa: Cupimus autem unumquemque vestrum eandem ostentare solicitudinem ad expletionem spei usque in finem:

verses.textEn: so that you may not be slow to act, but instead may be imitators of those who, through faith and patience, shall inherit the promises.
verses.textLa: ut non segnes efficiamini, verum imitatores eorum, qui fide, et patientia hereditabunt promissiones.

verses.textEn: For God, in making promises to Abraham, swore by himself, (because he had no one greater by whom he might swear),
verses.textLa: Abrahæ namque promittens Deus, quoniam neminem habuit, per quem iuraret, maiorem, iuravit per semetipsum,

verses.textEn: saying: “Blessing, I shall bless you, and multiplying, I shall multiply you.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Nisi benedicens benedicam te, et multiplicans multiplicabo te.
verses.notes: The word ‘nisi,’ which usually means ‘except’ or ‘unless’ (or, literally, ‘if not’), in this context indicates an oath or a swearing to something. It is like saying, “If I do not do this thing that I swear to do (or, “Unless I do this thing that I swear to do”), then may that bad thing happen to me.” However, the latter part of stating the bad thing is left off, in this case because God cannot fail to accomplish what He has sworn, and because nothing bad can happen to God.

verses.textEn: And in this way, by enduring patiently, he secured the promise.
verses.textLa: Et sic longanimiter ferens, adeptus est repromissionem.

verses.textEn: For men swear by what is greater than themselves, and an oath as confirmation is the end of all their controversy.
verses.textLa: Homines enim per maiorem sui iurant: et omnis controversiæ eorum finis, ad confirmationem, est iuramentum.

verses.textEn: In this matter, God, wanting to reveal more thoroughly the immutability of his counsel to the heirs of the promise, interposed an oath,
verses.textLa: In quo abundantius volens Deus ostendere pollicitationis heredibus immobilitatem consilii sui, interposuit iusiurandum:

verses.textEn: so that by two immutable things, in which it is impossible for God to lie, we may have the strongest solace: we who have fled together so as to hold fast to the hope set before us.
verses.textLa: ut per duas res immobiles, quibus impossibile est mentiri Deum, fortissimum solatium habeamus, qui confugimus ad tenendam propositam spem,

verses.textEn: This we have as an anchor of the soul, safe and sound, which advances even to the interior of the veil,
verses.textLa: quam sicut anchoram habemus animæ tutam ac firmam, et incedentem usque ad interiora velaminis,

verses.textEn: to the place where the forerunner Jesus has entered on our behalf, so as to become the High Priest for eternity, according to the order of Melchizedek.
verses.textLa: ubi præcursor pro nobis introivit Iesus, secundum ordinem Melchisedech Pontifex factus in æternum.

verses.textEn: For this Melchizedek, king of Salem, priest of the Most High God, met Abraham, as he was returning from the slaughter of the kings, and blessed him.
verses.textLa: Hic enim Melchisedech, rex Salem, sacerdos Dei summi, qui obviavit Abrahæ regresso a cæde regum, et benedixit ei:

verses.textEn: And Abraham divided to him a tenth part of everything. And in translation his name is first, indeed, king of justice, and next also king of Salem, that is, king of peace.
verses.textLa: cui et decimas omnium divisit Abraham: primum quidem qui interpretatur rex iustitiæ: deinde autem et rex Salem, quod est, rex pacis,
verses.notes: The name Melchizedek means ‘my king is righteous.’ The word ‘Salem’ means ‘peace,’ as in the word ‘Shalom.’

verses.textEn: Without father, without mother, without genealogy, having neither beginning of days, nor end of life, he is thereby likened to the Son of God, who remains a priest continuously.
verses.textLa: sine patre, sine matre, sine genealogia, neque initium dierum, neque finem vitæ habens, assimilatus autem Filio Dei, manet sacerdos in perpetuum.
verses.notes: Melchizedek is presented to us without any information about his father, mother, genealogy, or the beginning or end of his life; he certainly had all these things. But in being presented without this information, he becomes likened to the Son of God, who has existed always and who has always been the same in his immutable Divine nature. Of course, even Christ, in his human nature, has a mother and a genealogy, and a beginning and end of his human life.

verses.textEn: Next, consider how great this man is, since the Patriarch Abraham even gave tithes to him from the principal things.
verses.textLa: Intuemini autem quantus sit hic, cui et decimas dedit de præcipuis Abraham patriarcha.

verses.textEn: And indeed, those who are from the sons of Levi, having received the priesthood, hold a commandment to take tithes from the people in accord with the law, that is, from their brothers, even though they also went forth from the loins of Abraham.
verses.textLa: Et quidem de filiis Levi sacerdotium accipientes, mandatum habent decimas sumere a populo secundum legem, id est, a fratribus suis: quamquam et ipsi exierint de lumbis Abrahæ.

verses.textEn: But this man, whose lineage is not enumerated with them, received tithes from Abraham, and he blessed even the one who held the promises.
verses.textLa: Cuius autem generatio non annumeratur in eis, decimas sumpsit ab Abraham, et hunc, qui habebat repromissiones, benedixit.

verses.textEn: Yet this is without any contradiction, for what is less should be blessed by what is better.
verses.textLa: Sine ulla autem contradictione, quod minus est, a meliore benedicitur.

verses.textEn: And certainly, here, men who receive tithes still die; but there, he bears witness that he lives.
verses.textLa: Et hic quidem, decimas morientes homines accipiunt: ibi autem contestatur, quia vivit.

verses.textEn: And so it may be said that even Levi, who received tithes, was himself a tithe through Abraham.
verses.textLa: Et (ut ita dictum sit) per Abraham, et Levi, qui decimas accepit, decimatus est:

verses.textEn: For he was still in the loins of his father, when Melchizedek met him.
verses.textLa: adhuc enim in lumbis patris erat, quando obviavit ei Melchisedech.

verses.textEn: Therefore, if consummation had occurred through the Levitical priesthood (for under it the people received the law), then what further need would there be for another Priest to rise up according to the order of Melchizedek, one who was not called according to the order of Aaron?
verses.textLa: Si ergo consummatio per sacerdotium Leviticum erat (populus enim sub ipso legem accepit) quid adhuc necessarium fuit secundum ordinem Melchisedech, alium surgere sacerdotem, et non secundum ordinem Aaron dici?

verses.textEn: For since the priesthood has been transferred, it is necessary that the law also be transferred.
verses.textLa: Translato enim sacerdotio, necesse erat ut et legis translatio fiat.

verses.textEn: For he about whom these things have been spoken is from another tribe, in which no one attends before the altar.
verses.textLa: In quo enim hæc dicuntur, de alia tribu est, de qua nullus altari præsto fuit.

verses.textEn: For it is evident that our Lord arose out of Judah, a tribe about which Moses said nothing concerning priests.
verses.textLa: Manifestum est enim quod ex Iuda ortus sit Dominus noster: in qua tribu nihil de sacerdotibus Moyses locutus est.

verses.textEn: And yet it is far more evident that, according to the likeness of Melchizedek, there rises up another priest,
verses.textLa: Et amplius adhuc manifestum est: si secundum similitudinem Melchisedech exurgat alius sacerdos,

verses.textEn: who was made, not according to the law of a carnal commandment, but according to the virtue of an indissoluble life.
verses.textLa: qui non secundum legem mandati carnalis factus est, sed secundum virtutem vitæ insolubilis.

verses.textEn: For he testifies: “You are a priest forever, according to the order of Melchizedek.”
verses.textLa: Contestatur enim: Quoniam tu es sacerdos in æternum, secundum ordinem Melchisedech.

verses.textEn: Certainly, there is a setting aside of the former commandment, because of its weakness and lack of usefulness.
verses.textLa: Reprobatio quidem fit præcedentis mandati, propter infirmitatem eius, et inutilitatem:

verses.textEn: For the law led no one to perfection, yet truly it introduced a better hope, through which we draw near to God.
verses.textLa: nihil enim ad perfectum adduxit lex: introductio vero melioris spei, per quam proximamus ad Deum.

verses.textEn: Moreover, it is not without an oath. For certainly, the others were made priests without an oath.
verses.textLa: Et quantum est non sine iureiurando (alii quidem sine iureiurando sacerdotes facti sunt,

verses.textEn: But this man was made a priest with an oath, by the One who said to him: “The Lord has sworn and he will not repent. You are a priest forever.”
verses.textLa: hic autem cum iureiurando per eum, qui dixit ad illum: Iuravit Dominus, et non pœnitebit eum: tu es sacerdos in æternum):

verses.textEn: By so much, Jesus has been made the sponsor of a better testament.
verses.textLa: in tantum melioris testamenti sponsor factus est Iesus.

verses.textEn: And certainly, so many of the others became priests because, due to death, they were prohibited from continuing.
verses.textLa: Et alii quidem plures facti sunt sacerdotes, idcirco quod morte prohiberentur permanere:

verses.textEn: But this man, because he continues forever, has an everlasting priesthood.
verses.textLa: hic autem eo quod maneat in æternum, sempiternum habet sacerdotium.

verses.textEn: And for this reason, he is able, continuously, to save those who approach God through him, since he is ever alive to make intercession on our behalf.
verses.textLa: Unde et salvare in perpetuum potest accedentes per semetipsum ad Deum: semper vivens ad interpellandum pro nobis.

verses.textEn: For it was fitting that we should have such a High Priest: holy, innocent, undefiled, set apart from sinners, and exalted higher than the heavens.
verses.textLa: Talis enim decebat ut nobis esset Pontifex, sanctus, innocens, impollutus, segregatus a peccatoribus, et excelsior cælis factus:

verses.textEn: And he has no need, daily, in the manner of other priests, to offer sacrifices, first for his own sins, and then for those of the people. For he has done this once, by offering himself.
verses.textLa: qui non habet necessitatem quotidie, quemadmodum sacerdotes, prius pro suis delictis hostias offerre, deinde pro populi: hoc enim fecit semel, seipsum offerendo.

verses.textEn: For the law appoints men as priests, though they have infirmities. But, by the word of the oath that is after the law, the Son has been perfected for eternity.
verses.textLa: Lex enim homines constituit sacerdotes infirmitatem habentes: sermo autem iurisiurandi, qui post legem est, Filium in æternum perfectum.

verses.textEn: Now the main point in the things that have been stated is this: that we have so great a High Priest, who is seated at the right hand of the throne of Majesty in the heavens,
verses.textLa: Capitulum autem super ea, quæ dicuntur: Talem habemus Pontificem, qui consedit in dextera sedis magnitudinis in cælis,

verses.textEn: who is the minister of holy things, and of the true tabernacle, which was established by the Lord, not by man.
verses.textLa: sanctorum minister, et tabernaculi veri, quod fixit Dominus, et non homo.

verses.textEn: For every high priest is appointed to offer gifts and sacrifices. Therefore, it is necessary for him also to have something to offer.
verses.textLa: Omnis enim pontifex ad offerendum munera, et hostias constituitur: unde necesse est et hunc habere aliquid, quod offerat:

verses.textEn: And so, if he were upon the earth, he would not be a priest, since there would be others to offer gifts according to the law,
verses.textLa: si ergo esset super terram, nec esset sacerdos: cum essent qui offerent secundum legem munera,

verses.textEn: gifts which serve as mere examples and shadows of the heavenly things. And so it was answered to Moses, when he was about to complete the tabernacle: “See to it,” he said, “that you make everything according to the example which was revealed to you on the mountain.”
verses.textLa: qui exemplari, et umbræ deserviunt cælestium. Sicut responsum est Moysi, cum consummaret tabernaculum: Vide (inquit) omnia facito secundum exemplar, quod tibi ostensum est in monte.

verses.textEn: But now he has been granted a better ministry, so much so that he is also the Mediator of a better testament, which has been confirmed by better promises.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem melius sortitus est ministerium, quanto et melioris testamenti mediator est, quod in melioribus repromissionibus sancitum est.

verses.textEn: For if the former one had been entirely without fault, then a place certainly would not have been sought for a subsequent one.
verses.textLa: Nam si illud prius culpa vacasset: non utique secundi locus inquireretur.

verses.textEn: For, finding fault with them, he says: “Behold, the days shall arrive, says the Lord, when I will consummate a New Testament over the house of Israel and the house of Judah,
verses.textLa: Vituperans enim eos dicit: Ecce dies venient, dicit Dominus: et consummabo super domum Israel, et super domum Iuda testamentum novum,

verses.textEn: not according to the testament which I made with their fathers, on the day when I took them by the hand, so that I might lead them away from the land of Egypt. For they did not remain in my testament, and so I disregarded them, says the Lord.
verses.textLa: non secundum testamentum, quod feci patribus eorum in die, qua apprehendi manum eorum ut educerem illos de Terra Ægypti: quoniam ipsi non permanserunt in testamento meo: et ego neglexi eos, dicit Dominus:

verses.textEn: For this is the testament which I will set before the house of Israel, after those days, says the Lord. I will instill my laws in their minds, and I will inscribe my laws on their hearts. And so, I will be their God, and they shall be my people.
verses.textLa: Quia hoc est testamentum, quod disponam domui Israel post dies illos, dicit Dominus: Dando leges meas in mentem eorum, et in corde eorum superscribam eas: et ero eis in Deum, et ipsi erunt mihi in populum:

verses.textEn: And they will not teach, each one his neighbor, and each one his brother, saying: ‘Know the Lord.’ For all shall know me, from the least, even to the greatest of them.
verses.textLa: et non docebit unusquisque proximum suum, et unusquisque fratrem suum, dicens: Cognosce Dominum: quoniam omnes scient me a minore usque ad maiorem eorum:

verses.textEn: For I will forgive their iniquities, and I will no longer remember their sins.”
verses.textLa: quia propitius ero iniquitatibus eorum, et peccatorum eorum iam non memorabor.

verses.textEn: Now in saying something new, he has made the former old. But that which decays and grows old is close to passing away.
verses.textLa: Dicendo autem novum: veteravit prius. Quod autem antiquatur, et senescit, prope interitum est.

verses.textEn: Certainly, the former also had the justifications of worship and a holy place for that age.
verses.textLa: Habuit quidem et prius, iustificationes culturæ, et sanctum sæculare.

verses.textEn: For a tabernacle was made at first, in which were the lampstand, and the table, and the bread of the Presence, which is called Holy.
verses.textLa: Tabernaculum enim factum est primum, in quo erant candelabra, et mensa, et propositio panum, quæ dicitur Sancta.

verses.textEn: Then, beyond the second veil, was the tabernacle, which is called the Holy of Holies,
verses.textLa: Post velamentum autem secundum, tabernaculum, quod dicitur Sancta sanctorum:

verses.textEn: having a golden censer, and the ark of the testament, covered all around and on every part with gold, in which was a golden urn containing manna, and the rod of Aaron which had blossomed, and the tablets of the testament.
verses.textLa: aureum habens thuribulum, et arcam testamenti circumtectam ex omni parte auro, in qua urna aurea habens manna, et virga Aaron, quæ fronduerat, et tabulæ testamenti,

verses.textEn: And over the ark were the Cherubim of glory, overshadowing the propitiatory. There is not enough time to speak about each of these things.
verses.textLa: superque eam erant Cherubim gloriæ obumbrantia propitiatorium: de quibus non est modo dicendum per singula.
verses.notes: The word ‘modo’ in this context refers to the limits of time or writing space which prevent the author from going into detail about all the items in the Tabernacle of the Old Testament.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, once such things were placed together, in the first part of the tabernacle, the priests were, indeed, continually entering, so as to carry out the duties of the sacrifices.
verses.textLa: His vero ita compositis: in priori quidem tabernaculo semper introibant sacerdotes, sacrificiorum officia consummantes:

verses.textEn: But into the second part, once a year, the high priest alone entered, not without blood, which he offered on behalf of the neglectful offenses of himself and of the people.
verses.textLa: in secundo autem semel in anno solus pontifex non sine sanguine, quem offert pro sua, et populi ignorantia:
verses.notes: See Numbers 15:22 and following, where sacrifices such as this one are prescribed for offenses whereby the people sin out of neglect or ignorance of the precepts of the Law. Thus, ‘ignorantia’ refers more to ‘offenses done out of ignorance or neglect,’ rather than merely a lack of knowledge.

verses.textEn: In this way, the Holy Spirit is signifying that the way to what is most holy was not yet made manifest, not while the first tabernacle was still standing.
verses.textLa: hoc significante Spiritu Sancto, nondum propalatam esse sanctorum viam, adhuc priore tabernaculo habente statum.

verses.textEn: And this is a parable for the present time. Accordingly, those gifts and sacrifices that are offered are not able, as concerns the conscience, to make perfect those things that serve only as food and drink,
verses.textLa: Quæ parabola est temporis instantis: iuxta quam munera, et hostiæ offeruntur, quæ non possunt iuxta conscientiam perfectum facere servientem, solummodo in cibis, et in potibus,

verses.textEn: as well as the various washings and justices of the flesh, which were imposed upon them until the time of correction.
verses.textLa: et variis baptismatibus, et iustitiis carnis usque ad tempus correctionis impositis.

verses.textEn: But Christ, standing as the High Priest of future good things, through a greater and more perfect tabernacle, one not made by hand, that is, not of this creation,
verses.textLa: Christus autem assistens Pontifex futurorum bonorum, per amplius et perfectius tabernaculum non manufactum, id est, non huius creationis:

verses.textEn: entered once into the Holy of Holies, having obtained eternal redemption, neither by the blood of goats, nor of calves, but by his own blood.
verses.textLa: neque per sanguinem hircorum, aut vitulorum, sed per proprium sanguinem introivit semel in Sancta, æterna redemptione inventa.

verses.textEn: For if the blood of goats and oxen, and the ashes of a calf, when these are sprinkled, sanctify those who have been defiled, in order to cleanse the flesh,
verses.textLa: Si enim sanguis hircorum, et taurorum, et cinis vitulæ aspersus inquinatos sanctificat ad emundationem carnis:

verses.textEn: how much more will the blood of Christ, who through the Holy Spirit has offered himself, immaculate, to God, cleanse our conscience from dead works, in order to serve the living God?
verses.textLa: quanto magis sanguis Christi, qui per Spiritum Sanctum semetipsum obtulit immaculatum Deo, emundabit conscientiam nostram ab operibus mortuis, ad serviendum Deo viventi?

verses.textEn: And thus he is the Mediator of the new testament, so that, by his death, he intercedes for the redemption of those transgressions which were under the former testament, so that those who have been called may receive the promise of an eternal inheritance.
verses.textLa: Et ideo novi testamenti Mediator est: ut morte intercedente, in redemptionem earum prævaricationum, quæ erant sub priori testamento, repromissionem accipiant qui vocati sunt æternæ hereditatis.

verses.textEn: For where there is a testament, it is necessary for the death of the one who testifies to intervene.
verses.textLa: Ubi enim testamentum est: mors necesse est intercedat testatoris.

verses.textEn: For a testament is confirmed by death. Otherwise, it as yet has no force, as long as the one who testifies lives.
verses.textLa: Testamentum enim in mortuis confirmatum est: alioquin nondum valet, dum vivit qui testatus est.

verses.textEn: Therefore, indeed, the first was not dedicated without blood.
verses.textLa: Unde nec primum quidem sine sanguine dedicatum est.

verses.textEn: For when every commandment of the law had been read by Moses to the entire people, he took up the blood of calves and goats, with water and with scarlet wool and hyssop, and he sprinkled both the book itself and the entire people,
verses.textLa: Lecto enim omni mandato legis a Moyse universo populo: accipiens sanguinem vitulorum et hircorum cum aqua et lana coccinea, et hyssopo: ipsum quoque librum, et omnem populum aspersit,

verses.textEn: saying: “This is the blood of the testament which God has commanded for you.”
verses.textLa: dicens: Hic sanguis testamenti, quod mandavit ad vos Deus.

verses.textEn: And even the tabernacle, and all the vessels for the ministry, he similarly sprinkled with blood.
verses.textLa: Etiam tabernaculum, et omnia vasa ministerii sanguine similiter aspersit:

verses.textEn: And nearly everything, according to the law, is to be cleansed with blood. And without the shedding of blood, there is no remission.
verses.textLa: Et omnia pene in sanguine secundum legem mundantur: et sine sanguinis effusione non fit remissio.

verses.textEn: Therefore, it is necessary for the examples of heavenly things to be cleansed, just as, indeed, these things were. Yet the heavenly things are themselves better sacrifices than these.
verses.textLa: Necesse est ergo exemplaria quidem cælestium his mundari: ipsa autem cælestia melioribus hostiis quam istis.

verses.textEn: For Jesus did not enter by means of holy things made with hands, mere examples of the true things, but he entered into Heaven itself, so that he may appear now before the face of God for us.
verses.textLa: Non enim in manufacta Sancta Iesus introivit exemplaria verorum: sed in ipsum Cælum, ut appareat nunc vultui Dei pro nobis:

verses.textEn: And he did not enter so as to offer himself repeatedly, as the high priest enters into the Holy of Holies each year, with the blood of another.
verses.textLa: Neque ut sæpe offerat semetipsum, quemadmodum pontifex intrat in Sancta per singulos annos in sanguine alieno:

verses.textEn: Otherwise, he would need to have suffered repeatedly since the beginning of the world. But now, one time, at the consummation of the ages, he has appeared in order to destroy sin though his own sacrifice.
verses.textLa: alioquin oportebat eum frequenter pati ab origine mundi: nunc autem semel in consummatione sæculorum, ad destitutionem peccati, per hostiam suam apparuit.

verses.textEn: And in the same manner as it has been appointed for men to die one time, and after this, to be judged,
verses.textLa: Et quemadmodum statutum est hominibus semel mori, post hoc autem iudicium:

verses.textEn: so also Christ was offered, one time, in order to empty the sins of so many. He shall appear a second time without sin, for those who await him, unto salvation.
verses.textLa: sic et Christus semel oblatus est ad multorum exhaurienda peccata: secundo sine peccato apparebit expectantibus se, in salutem.

verses.textEn: For the law contains the shadow of future good things, not the very image of these things. So, by the very same sacrifices which they offer ceaselessly each year, they can never cause these to approach perfection.
verses.textLa: Umbram enim habens lex futurorum bonorum, non ipsam imaginem rerum: per singulos annos eisdem ipsis hostiis, quas offerunt indesinenter, numquam potest accedentes perfectos facere:

verses.textEn: Otherwise, they would have ceased to be offered, because the worshipers, once cleansed, would no longer be conscious of any sin.
verses.textLa: alioquin cessassent offerri: ideo quod nullam haberent ultra conscientiam peccati, cultores semel mundati:

verses.textEn: Instead, in these things, a commemoration of sins is made every year.
verses.textLa: sed in ipsis commemoratio peccatorum per singulos annos fit.

verses.textEn: For it is impossible for sins to be taken away by the blood of oxen and goats.
verses.textLa: Impossibile enim est sanguine taurorum et hircorum auferri peccata.

verses.textEn: For this reason, as Christ enters into the world, he says: “Sacrifice and oblation, you did not want. But you have fashioned a body for me.
verses.textLa: Ideo ingrediens mundum dicit: Hostiam, et oblationem noluisti: corpus autem aptasti mihi:

verses.textEn: Holocausts for sin were not pleasing to you.
verses.textLa: holocautomata pro peccato non tibi placuerunt.

verses.textEn: Then I said, ‘Behold, I draw near.’ At the head of the book, it has been written of me that I should do your will, O God.”
verses.textLa: Tunc dixi: Ecce venio: in capite libri scriptum est de me: Ut faciam, Deus, voluntatem tuam.

verses.textEn: In the above, by saying, “Sacrifices, and oblations, and holocausts for sin, you did not want, nor are those things pleasing to you, which are offered according to the law;
verses.textLa: Superius dicens: Quia hostias, et oblationes, et holocautomata pro peccato noluisti, nec placita sunt tibi, quæ secundum legem offeruntur,

verses.textEn: then I said, ‘Behold, I have come to do your will, O God,’ ” he takes away the first, so that he may establish what follows.
verses.textLa: tunc dixi: Ecce venio, ut faciam, Deus, voluntatem tuam: aufert primum, ut sequens statuat.
verses.notes: Notice that Sacred Scripture gives two quotes in succession. The first is a precise quote from Psalm 39; the second is a looser, free quotation from the same source, but which rephrases it and omits some parts. In this way, Scripture indicates the range of quotations of Scripture which are acceptable to God.

verses.textEn: For by this will, we have been sanctified, through the one time oblation of the body of Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: In qua voluntate sanctificati sumus per oblationem corporis Iesu Christi semel.

verses.textEn: And certainly, every priest stands by, ministering daily, and frequently offering the same sacrifices, which are never able to take away sins.
verses.textLa: Et omnis quidem sacerdos præsto est quotidie ministrans, et easdem sæpe offerens hostias, quæ numquam possunt auferre peccata:

verses.textEn: But this man, offering one sacrifice for sins, sits at the right hand of God forever,
verses.textLa: hic autem unam pro peccatis offerens hostiam, in sempiternum sedet in dextera Dei,

verses.textEn: awaiting that time when his enemies will be made his footstool.
verses.textLa: de cetero expectans donec ponantur inimici eius scabellum pedum eius.

verses.textEn: For, by one oblation, he has brought to fulfillment, for all time, those who are sanctified.
verses.textLa: Una enim oblatione, consummavit in sempiternum sanctificatos.

verses.textEn: Now the Holy Spirit also testifies for us about this. For afterward, he said:
verses.textLa: Contestatur autem nos et Spiritus Sanctus. Postquam enim dixit:

verses.textEn: “And this is the testament which I will commit to them after those days, says the Lord. I will instill my laws in their hearts, and I will inscribe my laws on their minds.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem testamentum, quod testabor ad illos post dies illos, dicit Dominus. Dando leges meas in cordibus eorum, et in mentibus eorum superscribam eas:

verses.textEn: And I will no longer remember their sins and iniquities.”
verses.textLa: et peccatorum, et iniquitatum eorum iam non recordabor amplius.

verses.textEn: Now, when there is a remission of these things, there is no longer an oblation for sin.
verses.textLa: Ubi autem horum remissio: iam non est oblatio pro peccato.

verses.textEn: And so, brothers, have faith in the entrance into the Holy of Holies by the blood of Christ,
verses.textLa: Habentes itaque fratres fiduciam in introitu sanctorum in sanguine Christi,

verses.textEn: and in the new and living Way, which he has initiated for us by the veil, that is, by his flesh,
verses.textLa: quam initiavit nobis viam novam, et viventem per velamen, id est, carnem suam,

verses.textEn: and in the Great Priest over the house of God.
verses.textLa: et sacerdotem magnum super domum Dei:

verses.textEn: So, let us draw near with a true heart, in the fullness of faith, having hearts cleansed from an evil conscience, and bodies absolved with clean water.
verses.textLa: accedamus cum vero corde in plenitudine fidei, aspersi corda a conscientia mala, et abluti corpus aqua munda,

verses.textEn: Let us hold fast to the confession of our hope, without wavering, for he who has promised is faithful.
verses.textLa: teneamus spei nostræ confessionem indeclinabilem, (fidelis enim est qui repromisit),

verses.textEn: And let us be considerate of one another, so as to prompt ourselves to charity and to good works,
verses.textLa: et consideremus invicem in provocationem charitatis, et bonorum operum:

verses.textEn: not deserting our assembly, as some are accustomed to do, but consoling one another, and even more so as you see that the day is approaching.
verses.textLa: non deserentes collectionem nostram, sicut consuetudinis est quibusdam, sed consolantes, et tanto magis quanto videritis appropinquantem diem.

verses.textEn: For if we sin willingly, after receiving knowledge of the truth, there is no sacrifice remaining for sins,
verses.textLa: Voluntarie enim peccantibus nobis post acceptam notitiam veritatis, iam non relinquitur pro peccatis hostia,

verses.textEn: but instead, a certain terrible expectation of judgment, and the rage of a fire that shall consume its adversaries.
verses.textLa: terribilis autem quædam expectatio iudicii, et ignis æmulatio, quæ consumptura est adversarios.

verses.textEn: If someone dies for acting against the law of Moses, and is shown no compassion because of two or three witnesses,
verses.textLa: Irritam quis faciens legem Moysi, sine ulla miseratione duobus vel tribus testibus moritur:

verses.textEn: how much more, do you think, someone would deserve worse punishments, if he has tread upon the Son of God, and has treated the blood of the testament, by which he was sanctified, as unclean, and has acted with disgrace toward the Spirit of grace?
verses.textLa: quanto magis putatis deteriora mereri supplicia qui Filium Dei conculcaverit, et sanguinem testamenti pollutum duxerit, in quo sanctificatus est, et Spiritui gratiæ contumeliam fecerit?

verses.textEn: For we know that he has said: “Vengeance is mine, and I will repay,” and again, “The Lord will judge his people.”
verses.textLa: Scimus enim qui dixit: Mihi vindicta, et ego retribuam. Et iterum: Quia iudicabit Dominus populum suum.

verses.textEn: It is dreadful to fall into the hands of the living God.
verses.textLa: Horrendum est incidere in manus Dei viventis.

verses.textEn: But call to mind the former days, in which, after being enlightened, you endured a great struggle of afflictions.
verses.textLa: Rememoramini autem pristinos dies, in quibus illuminati, magnum certamen sustinuistis passionum:

verses.textEn: And certainly, in one way, by insults and tribulations, you were made a spectacle, but in another way, you became the companions of those who were the object of such behavior.
verses.textLa: et in altero quidem opprobriis, et tribulationibus spectaculum facti: in altero autem socii taliter conversantium effecti.

verses.textEn: For you even had compassion on those who were imprisoned, and you accepted with gladness being deprived of your goods, knowing that you have a better and more lasting substance.
verses.textLa: Nam et vinctis compassi estis, et rapinam bonorum vestrorum cum gaudio suscepistis, cognoscentes vos habere meliorem, et manentem substantiam.

verses.textEn: And so, do not lose your confidence, which has a great reward.
verses.textLa: Nolite itaque amittere confidentiam vestram, quæ magnam habet remunerationem.

verses.textEn: For it is necessary for you to be patient, so that, by doing the will of God, you may receive the promise.
verses.textLa: Patientia enim vobis necessaria est: ut voluntatem Dei facientes, reportetis promissionem.

verses.textEn: “For, in a little while, and somewhat longer, he who is to come will return, and he will not delay.
verses.textLa: Adhuc enim modicum aliquantulum, qui venturus est, veniet, et non tardabit.
verses.notes: An indication of two Returns of Christ is found in this verse, for it says that he returns in a little while, but then another return, somewhat further into the future, is mentioned next. This is followed by a statement of his Return, and then another such statement, where it says that he will not delay.

verses.textEn: For my just man lives by faith. But if he were to draw himself back, he would not please my soul.”
verses.textLa: Iustus autem meus ex fide vivit. Quod si subtraxerit se, non placebit animæ meæ.

verses.textEn: So then, we are not sons who are drawn away to perdition, but we are sons of faith toward the securing of the soul.
verses.textLa: Nos autem non sumus subtractionis filii in perditionem, sed fidei in acquisitionem animæ.

verses.textEn: Now, faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not apparent.
verses.textLa: Est autem fides sperandarum substantia rerum, argumentum non apparentium.

verses.textEn: For this reason, the ancients were given testimony.
verses.textLa: In hac enim testimonium consecuti sunt senes.

verses.textEn: By faith, we understand the world to be fashioned by the Word of God, so that the visible might be made by the invisible.
verses.textLa: Fide intelligimus aptata esse sæcula verbo Dei: ut ex invisibilibus visibilia fierent.

verses.textEn: By faith, Abel offered to God a much better sacrifice than that of Cain, through which he obtained testimony that he was just, in that God offered testimony to his gifts. And through that sacrifice, he still speaks to us, though he is dead.
verses.textLa: Fide plurimam hostiam Abel, quam Cain, obtulit Deo, per quam testimonium consecutus est esse iustus, testimonium perhibente muneribus eius Deo, et per illam defunctus adhuc loquitur.

verses.textEn: By faith, Enoch was transferred, so that he would not see death, and he was not found because God had transferred him. For before he was transferred, he had testimony that he pleased God.
verses.textLa: Fide Henoch translatus est ne videret mortem, et non inveniebatur: quia transtulit illum Deus: ante translationem enim testimonium habuit placuisse Deo.
verses.notes: Henoch, in my opinion, was transferred to that future time spoken of in the Book of Revelation, since he is one of the two prophets.

verses.textEn: But without faith, it is impossible to please God. For whoever approaches God must believe that he exists, and that he rewards those who seek him.
verses.textLa: Sine fide autem impossibile est placere Deo. Credere enim oportet accedentem ad Deum quia est, et inquirentibus se remunerator sit.

verses.textEn: By faith, Noah, having accepted an answer about those things which were not yet seen, being afraid, fashioned an ark for the salvation of his house. Through the ark, he condemned the world, and was established as the heir of the justice that occurs through faith.
verses.textLa: Fide Noe responso accepto de iis, quæ adhuc non videbantur, metuens aptavit arcam in salutem domus suæ, per quam damnavit mundum: et iustitiæ, quæ per fidem est, heres est institutus.

verses.textEn: By faith, the one called Abraham obeyed, going out to the place that he was to receive as an inheritance. And he went out, not knowing where he was going.
verses.textLa: Fide qui vocatur Abraham obedivit in locum exire, quem accepturus erat in hereditatem: et exiit, nesciens quo iret.

verses.textEn: By faith, he stayed in the Land of the Promise as if in a foreign land, dwelling in cottages, with Isaac and Jacob, co-heirs of the same promise.
verses.textLa: Fide demoratus est in Terra repromissionis, tamquam in aliena, in casulis habitando cum Isaac, et Iacob coheredibus repromissionis eiusdem.

verses.textEn: For he was awaiting a city having firm foundations, whose designer and builder is God.
verses.textLa: Expectabat enim fundamenta habentem civitatem: cuius artifex, et conditor Deus.

verses.textEn: By faith also, Sarah herself, being barren, received the ability to conceive offspring, even though she was past that age in life. For she believed him to be faithful, who had promised.
verses.textLa: Fide et ipsa Sara sterilis virtutem in conceptionem seminis accepit, etiam præter tempus ætatis: quoniam fidelem credidit esse eum, qui repromiserat.

verses.textEn: Because of this, there were also born, from one who himself was as if dead, a multitude like the stars of heaven, who are, like the sand of the seashore, innumerable.
verses.textLa: Propter quod et ab uno orti sunt (et hoc emortuo) tamquam sidera cæli in multitudinem, et sicut arena, quæ est ad oram maris, innumerabilis.

verses.textEn: All of these passed away, adhering to faith, not having received the promises, yet beholding them from afar and saluting them, and confessing themselves to be sojourners and guests upon the earth.
verses.textLa: Iuxta fidem defuncti sunt omnes isti, non acceptis repromissionibus, sed a longe eas aspicientes, et salutantes, et confitentes quia peregrini, et hospites sunt super terram.

verses.textEn: For those who speak in this way are themselves indicating that they seek a homeland.
verses.textLa: Qui enim hæc dicunt, significant se patriam inquirere.

verses.textEn: And if, indeed, they had been mindful of the very place from which they departed, they certainly would have returned in time.
verses.textLa: Et si quidem ipsius meminissent de qua exierunt, habebant utique tempus revertendi.

verses.textEn: But now they hunger for a better place, that is, Heaven. For this reason, God is not ashamed to be called their God. For he has prepared a city for them.
verses.textLa: Nunc autem meliorem appetunt, id est, cælestem. Ideo non confunditur Deus vocari Deus eorum: paravit enim illis civitatem.

verses.textEn: By faith, Abraham, when he was tested, offered Isaac, so that he who had received the promises was offering up his only son.
verses.textLa: Fide obtulit Abraham Isaac, cum tentaretur, et unigenitum offerebat, qui susceperat repromissiones;

verses.textEn: To him, it was said, “Through Isaac, shall your offspring be summoned,”
verses.textLa: ad quem dictum est: Quia in Isaac vocabitur tibi semen:

verses.textEn: indicating that God is even able to raise up from the dead. And thus, he also established him as a parable.
verses.textLa: arbitrans quia et a mortuis suscitare potens est Deus: unde eum et in parabolam accepit.

verses.textEn: By faith, also, Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau, concerning future events.
verses.textLa: Fide et de futuris benedixit Isaac Iacob, et Esau.

verses.textEn: By faith, Jacob, as he was dying, blessed each of the sons of Joseph; and he reverenced the summit of his rod.
verses.textLa: Fide Iacob, moriens, singulos filiorum Ioseph benedixit: et adoravit fastigium virgæ eius.

verses.textEn: By faith, Joseph, as he was dying, recalled the departure of the sons of Israel, and gave a commandment concerning his bones.
verses.textLa: Fide Ioseph, moriens, de profectione filiorum Israel memoratus est, et de ossibus suis mandavit.

verses.textEn: By faith, Moses, after being born, was hidden for three months by his parents, because they had seen that he was a graceful infant, and they did not fear the king’s edict.
verses.textLa: Fide Moyses, natus, occultatus est mensibus tribus a parentibus suis, eo quod vidissent elegantem infantem, et non timuerunt regis edictum.

verses.textEn: By faith, Moses, after growing up, denied himself a place as the son of Pharaoh’s daughter,
verses.textLa: Fide Moyses grandis factus negavit se esse filium filiæ Pharaonis,

verses.textEn: choosing to be afflicted with the people of God, rather than to have the pleasantness of sin for a time,
verses.textLa: magis eligens affligi cum populo Dei, quam temporalis peccati habere iucunditatem,

verses.textEn: valuing the reproach of Christ to be a greater wealth than the treasures of the Egyptians. For he looked forward to his reward.
verses.textLa: maiores divitias æstimans thesauro Ægyptiorum, improperium Christi: aspiciebat enim in remunerationem.
verses.notes: Notice that even before the time of Jesus Christ, Scripture clearly indicates that the faith of the Patriarchs was an implicit faith in Christ.

verses.textEn: By faith, he abandoned Egypt, not dreading the animosity of the king. For he pressed on, as if seeing him who is unseen.
verses.textLa: Fide reliquit Ægyptum, non veritus animositatem regis: invisibilem enim tamquam videns sustinuit.

verses.textEn: By faith, he celebrated the Passover and the shedding of the blood, so that he who destroyed the firstborn might not touch them.
verses.textLa: Fide celebravit Pascha, et sanguinis effusionem: ne qui vastabat primitiva, tangeret eos.

verses.textEn: By faith, they crossed the Red Sea, as if on dry land, yet when the Egyptians attempted it, they were swallowed up.
verses.textLa: Fide transierunt Mare Rubrum tamquam per aridam terram: quod experti Ægyptii, devorati sunt.

verses.textEn: By faith, the walls of Jericho collapsed, after being encircled for seven days.
verses.textLa: Fide muri Iericho corruerunt, circuitu dierum septem.

verses.textEn: By faith, Rahab, the harlot, did not perish with the unbelievers, after receiving the spies with peace.
verses.textLa: Fide Rahab meretrix non periit cum incredulis, excipiens exploratores cum pace.

verses.textEn: And what should I say next? For time is not sufficient for me to give an account of Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, David, Samuel, and the Prophets:
verses.textLa: Et quid adhuc dicam? Deficiet enim me tempus enarrantem de Gedeon, Barac, Samson, Iephte, David, Samuel, et Prophetis:

verses.textEn: those who, by faith, conquered kingdoms, accomplished justice, obtained promises, closed the mouths of lions,
verses.textLa: qui per fidem vicerunt regna, operati sunt iustitiam, adepti sunt repromissiones, obturaverunt ora leonum,

verses.textEn: extinguished the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, recovered from infirmities, showed strength in battle, turned back the armies of foreigners.
verses.textLa: extinxerunt impetum ignis, effugerunt aciem gladii, convaluerunt de infirmitate, fortes facti sunt in bello, castra verterunt exterorum:

verses.textEn: Women received their dead by means of resurrection. But others suffered severe punishment, not yet receiving redemption, so that they would find a better resurrection.
verses.textLa: acceperunt mulieres de resurrectione mortuos suos: alii autem distenti sunt non suscipientes redemptionem, ut meliorem invenirent resurrectionem.
verses.notes: The verb ‘distenti sunt’ indicates that this suffering is a punishment for offenses, in other words, a metaphor for Purgatory. So this part does not refer to an unjust persecution, nor to the unending suffering of Hell. For those in Purgatory suffer after death, yet find a better resurrection after their suffering. Literally, the verb refers to being racked (stretched out on a rack as an ancient form of severe punishment). The sufferings of Purgatory are more severe than any tortures of earth, although in Purgatory, the faithful souls there only have souls, not bodies, so their sufferings are spiritual only, not physical.

verses.textEn: Truly, others were tested by mocking and lashes, and moreover by chains and imprisonment.
verses.textLa: Alii vero ludibria, et verbera experti, insuper et vincula, et carceres:

verses.textEn: They were stoned; they were cut; they were tempted. With the slaughter of the sword, they were killed. They wandered about in sheepskin and in goatskin, in dire need, in anguish afflicted.
verses.textLa: lapidati sunt, secti sunt, tentati sunt, in occisione gladii mortui sunt, circuierunt in melotis, in pellibus caprinis, egentes, angustiati, afflicti:

verses.textEn: Of them, the world was not worthy, wandering in solitude on mountains, in the caves and caverns of the earth.
verses.textLa: quibus dignus non erat mundus: in solitudinibus errantes, in montibus, in speluncis, et in cavernis terræ.

verses.textEn: And all these, having been proven by the testimony of faith, did not receive the Promise.
verses.textLa: Et hi omnes testimonio fidei probati, non acceperunt repromissionem,

verses.textEn: God’s Providence holds something better for us, so that not without us would they be perfected.
verses.textLa: Deo pro nobis melius aliquid providente, ut non sine nobis consummarentur.

verses.textEn: Furthermore, since we also have so great a cloud of witnesses over us, let us set aside every burden and sin which may surround us, and advance, through patience, to the struggle offered to us.
verses.textLa: Ideoque et nos tantam habentes impositam nubem testium, deponentes omne pondus, et circumstans nos peccatum, per patientiam curramus ad propositum nobis certamen:

verses.textEn: Let us gaze upon Jesus, as the Author and the completion of our faith, who, having joy laid out before him, endured the cross, disregarding the shame, and who now sits at the right hand of the throne of God.
verses.textLa: aspicientes in Auctorem fidei, et consummatorem Iesum, qui proposito sibi gaudio sustinuit crucem, confusione contempta, atque in dextera sedis Dei sedet.

verses.textEn: So then, meditate upon him who endured such adversity from sinners against himself, so that you may not become weary, failing in your souls.
verses.textLa: Recogitate enim eum, qui talem sustinuit a peccatoribus adversum semetipsum contradictionem: ut ne fatigemini, animis vestris deficientes.

verses.textEn: For you have not yet resisted unto blood, while striving against sin.
verses.textLa: Nondum enim usque ad sanguinem restitistis, adversus peccatum repugnantes:

verses.textEn: And you have forgotten the consolation which speaks to you like sons, saying: “My son, do not be willing to neglect the discipline of the Lord. Neither should you become weary, while being rebuked by him.”
verses.textLa: et obliti estis consolationis, quæ vobis tamquam filiis loquitur, dicens: Fili mi, noli negligere disciplinam Domini: neque fatigeris dum ab eo argueris.

verses.textEn: For whomever the Lord loves, he chastises. And every son whom he accepts, he scourges.
verses.textLa: Quem enim diligit Dominus, castigat: flagellat autem omnem filium, quem recipit.

verses.textEn: Persevere in discipline. God presents you to himself as sons. But what son is there, whom his father does not correct?
verses.textLa: In disciplina perseverate. Tamquam filiis vobis offert se Deus: quis enim filius, quem non corripit pater?

verses.textEn: But if you are without that discipline in which all have become sharers, then you are of adultery, and you are not sons.
verses.textLa: Quod si extra disciplinam estis, cuius participes facti sunt omnes: ergo adulteri, et non filii estis.

verses.textEn: Then, too, we have certainly had the fathers of our flesh as instructors, and we reverenced them. Should we not obey the Father of spirits all the more, and so live?
verses.textLa: Deinde patres quidem carnis nostræ, eruditores habuimus, et reverebamur eos. Non multo magis obtemperabimus Patri spirituum, et vivemus?

verses.textEn: And indeed, for a few days and according to their own wishes, they instructed us. But he does so to our benefit, so that we may receive his sanctification.
verses.textLa: Et illi quidem in tempore paucorum dierum, secundum voluntatem suam erudiebant nos: hic autem ad id, quod utile est in recipiendo sanctificationem eius.

verses.textEn: Now every discipline, in the present time, does not seem a gladness, of course, but a grief. But afterwards, it will repay a most peaceful fruit of justice to those who become trained in it.
verses.textLa: Omnis autem disciplina in præsenti quidem videtur non esse gaudii, sed mœroris: postea autem fructum pacatissimum exercitatis per eam, reddet iustitiæ.

verses.textEn: Because of this, lift up your lazy hands and your lax knees,
verses.textLa: Propter quod remissas manus, et soluta genua, erigite,

verses.textEn: and straighten the path of your feet, so that no one, being lame, may wander astray, but instead may be healed.
verses.textLa: et gressus rectos facite pedibus vestris: ut non claudicans quis erret, magis autem sanetur.

verses.textEn: Pursue peace with everyone. Pursue sanctity, without which no one shall see God.
verses.textLa: Pacem sequimini cum omnibus, et sanctimoniam, sine qua nemo videbit Deum:

verses.textEn: Be contemplative, lest anyone lack the grace of God, lest any root of bitterness spring up and impede you, and by it, many might be defiled,
verses.textLa: contemplantes ne quis desit gratiæ Dei: ne qua radix amaritudinis sursum germinans impediat, et per illam inquinentur multi:

verses.textEn: lest any fornicator or worldly person be like Esau, who, for the sake of one meal, sold his birthright.
verses.textLa: ne quis fornicator, aut profanus ut Esau: qui propter unam escam vendidit primitiva sua:

verses.textEn: For you know that afterwards, when he desired to inherit the benediction, he was rejected. For he found no place for repentance, even though he had sought it with tears.
verses.textLa: scitote enim quoniam et postea cupiens hereditare benedictionem, reprobatus est: non enim invenit pœnitentiæ locum, quamquam cum lacrymis inquisisset eam.

verses.textEn: But you have not drawn near to a tangible mountain, or a burning fire, or a whirlwind, or a mist, or a storm,
verses.textLa: Non enim accessistis ad tractabilem montem, et accensibilem ignem, et turbinem, et caliginem, et procellam,

verses.textEn: or the sound of a trumpet, or a voice of words. Those who had experienced these things excused themselves, lest the Word be spoken to them.
verses.textLa: et tubæ sonum, et vocem verborum, quam qui audierunt, excusaverunt se, ne eis fieret verbum.

verses.textEn: For they could not bear what was said, and so, if even a beast would have touched the mountain, it would have been stoned.
verses.textLa: Non enim portabant quod dicebatur: Et si bestia tetigerit montem, lapidabitur.

verses.textEn: And what was seen was so terrible that even Moses said: “I am terrified, and so, I tremble.”
verses.textLa: Et ita terribile erat quod videbatur. Moyses dixit: Exterritus sum, et tremebundus.

verses.textEn: But you have drawn near to mount Zion, and to the city of the living God, to the heavenly Jerusalem, and to the company of many thousands of Angels,
verses.textLa: Sed accessistis ad Sion montem, et civitatem Dei viventis, Ierusalem cælestem, et multorum millium Angelorum frequentiam,

verses.textEn: and to the Church of the first-born, those who have been inscribed in the heavens, and to God, the judge of all, and to the spirits of the just made perfect,
verses.textLa: et Ecclesiam primitivorum, qui conscripti sunt in cælis, et iudicem omnium Deum, et spiritus iustorum perfectorum,

verses.textEn: and to Jesus, the Mediator of the New Testament, and to a sprinkling of blood, which speaks better than the blood of Abel.
verses.textLa: et testamenti novi mediatorem Iesum, et sanguinis aspersionem melius loquentem quam Abel.

verses.textEn: Be careful not to reject the One who is speaking. For if those who rejected him who was speaking upon the earth were not able to escape, so much more we who might turn away from the One who is speaking to us from heaven.
verses.textLa: Videte ne recusetis loquentem. Si enim illi non effugerunt, recusantes eum, qui super terram loquebatur: multo magis nos, qui de cælis loquentem nobis avertimus.

verses.textEn: Then, his voice moved the earth. But now, he makes a promise, saying: “There is still one more time, and then I will move, not only the earth, but also heaven itself.”
verses.textLa: Cuius vox movit terram tunc: nunc autem repromittit, dicens: Adhuc semel: et ego movebo non solum terram, sed et cælum.

verses.textEn: And so, in saying, “There is still one more time,” he declares the transfer of the moveable things of creation, so that those things which are immoveable may remain.
verses.textLa: Quod autem, Adhuc semel, dicit: declarat mobilium translationem tamquam factorum, ut maneant ea, quæ sunt immobilia.

verses.textEn: Thus, in receiving an immoveable kingdom, we have grace. So, through grace, let us be of service, by pleasing God with fear and reverence.
verses.textLa: Itaque regnum immobile suscipientes, habemus gratiam: per quam serviamus placentes Deo, cum metu et reverentia.

verses.textEn: For our God is a consuming fire.
verses.textLa: Etenim Deus noster ignis consumens est.

verses.textEn: May fraternal charity remain in you.
verses.textLa: Charitas fraternitatis maneat in vobis.

verses.textEn: And do not be willing to forget hospitality. For by it, certain persons, without realizing it, have received Angels as guests.
verses.textLa: Et hospitalitatem nolite oblivisci, per hanc enim latuerunt quidam, Angelis hospitio receptis.

verses.textEn: Remember those who are prisoners, just as if you were imprisoned with them, and those who endure hardships, just as if you were in their place.
verses.textLa: Mementote vinctorum, tamquam simul vincti: et laborantium, tamquam et ipsi in corpore morantes.
verses.notes: The word ‘labor’ does not necessarily refer to work; it often is used to refer to various kinds of hardships.
